content: {{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-261-10-B |Item_parent=Glomerular nephropathy |Item_parent_short=Glomerular nephropathy |Rank=B |Title=Know the main ways in which SNLGM develops |Description=Know the circumstances that suggest corticosteroid-sensitive, corticosteroid-resistant and corticosteroid-dependent NS. |Topic=Follow-up and/or prognosis |Contributors=Eric Daugas,Bruno Moulin |Order=10}} '''Evolution/ prognosis: 3 possibilities''' * Corticosensitivity (80-90% of cases): disappearance of proteinuria. Relapse after discontinuation of treatment in 50% of cases, necessitating resumption of corticosteroid therapy. * Corticodependence: relapse after corticosensitivity occurring when corticosteroid therapy is reduced or rapidly after it is stopped. Often requires the addition of an immunosuppressant or immunomodulator. * Corticoresistance: non-response (10% of cases), risk (50%) of end-stage chronic renal failure within 5 years.

question.question: What is the prognosis for a patient with SNLGM who does not respond to corticosteroid therapy?
question.option_a: Corticosteroid-dependent NS, requiring the addition of an immunosuppressant or immunomodulator
question.option_b: Corticosteroid-resistant NS, with a high risk of end-stage chronic renal failure within 5 years
question.option_c: Corticosteroid-sensitive NS, with a high likelihood of relapse after treatment discontinuation
question.option_d: Corticosteroid-independent NS, with a moderate risk of renal failure
